results.title: China and its agriculture
results.brief_description: Discusses the attempts by China to increase farm production to keep pace with the growth of its huge population. One method has been the establishment of communal farming. Shows China’s major agricultural products and explains the influence of cultural, social and political factors on the organization of agriculture.

results.title: China and it's industry
results.brief_description: Shows the major resources, raw materials and industries of China, and describes how these industries developed. Discusses the industrial workers, how they are trained and how they live.

results.title: China after Tianamen
results.creator_credit: Drasnin Productions, WGBH (Boston), Boston and Irv Drasnin
results.brief_description: On June 4th 1989, the world watched as the tanks rolled into Tianamen Square, dispersing the students who had carried out their non-violent protest for democratic reform in China. After Tianamen, China would never be the same. Paradoxically, along with the tightening of security, the increased presence of surveillence and miltary forces, there has been a rise in consumerism, entrepreneurship and commercialism as China takes it place in the global marketplace. This program looks at the aftermath of Tianamen, examining issues such as the state’s control of the arts, the expression of dissent, particularly reflected in the growing interest in religion, and the economic and social changes which are changing the face of China.

results.title: China - the red sons
results.creator_credit: Roger Whittaker Films and Roger Whittaker
results.brief_description: A tour of six Chinese cities in 1968 by a group of Australian and New Zealand students. Scenes of ordinary life and industry, and interviews with officials, students, Red Guards, foreign residents and others discussing the Cultural Revolution then in progress and the general situation, displaying the contrasting values of the visitors and their hosts. Narrated by Richard Oxenburgh.

results.title: China's child
results.brief_description: Looks at population control measures implemented in China and economic and sociological implications of these. Couples must be over twenty-four years of age before marrying and are told when to conceive a child.

results.title: Chimpanzees reared in darkness
results.creator_credit: Psychological Cinema Register and Pennsylvania State University
results.brief_description: Compares two chimpanzees that have been in complete darkness from birth to 18 months with normally reared infants. The experimental chimpanzees show a lack of visual fixations, absence of object recognition, and failure to discriminate familiar from strange persons. The chimpanzees present nystagmus of the blind and slowness of visual learning, with inaccuracies in reaching movements and dependence on tactual and kinesthetic cues, in contrast to the dependence on visual cues in normal infants. Silent film with English subtext.

results.title: Chillysmith farm
results.creator_credit: Valley Filmworks, Mark Jury and Dan Jury
results.brief_description: Chillysmith Farm was the home of Gramp, whose last years were documented by his grandsons in the photo essay ‘Gramp’. In this film, 10 years in the making, Gramp and other members of his family are shown. Birth and death are shown by the whole family. This is a film for all ages that raises issues of family life, birth, death, and individual responsibility of the ageing.

results.title: Chilean nitrate: gift of the desert
results.brief_description: Visualises the mining, refining and transportation of nitrate of soda in the Attacama Desert of Northern Chile. Tells of the discovery of the deposits by two American Indians. Shows the magnitude of refining operations in the area, stressing the isolation that employees of the industry must face. Describes a new form in which the nitrate can be readily stored in ships. States the importance of the industry to Chile.

results.title: Chilean hacienda: a traditional farm estate
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Film Enterprises and Clifford J. Kamen
results.brief_description: A relatively small part of Chile is suitable for farming but in this part are large farm estates, many owned by the descendants of the Spaniards who originally settled there. Employing as many as 1,000 employees, each hacienda will have its own shopping centre, school, and hospital. The employees give some of their time in payment for housing etc and also receive wages. The products are wheat, fruit, cattle, potatoes, and similar farm products. Amusements include dancing and rodeos. The haciendas are the core of the farming system of an agricultural nation.

results.title: Chile: hasta cuando?(Captioned)
results.brief_description: An account of the political unrest in Chile, 12 years after the murder of Allende and the installation of military dictatorship under General Pinochet. This powerful documentary is also about the struggle of the people of Chile. Under the dictatorship of Pinochet some 50,000 Chileans were detained, many are missing believed dead.
